name: NMDC
description:
Schema for National Microbiome Data Collaborative (NMDC).
This schema is organized into distinct modules:

 * a set of core types for representing data values
 * the mixs schema (auto-translated from mixs excel)
 * annotation schema
 * the NMDC schema itself
title: NMDC Schema

sample subset.name: sample subset
sample subset.description: Subset consisting of entities linked to the processing of samples.  Currently, this subset consists of study, omics process, and biosample.

data object subset.name: data object subset
data object subset.description: Subset consisting of the data objects that either inputs or outputs of processes or workflows.

external identifier.name: external identifier
external identifier.description: A CURIE representing an external identifier

bytes.name: bytes
bytes.description: An integer value that corresponds to a size in bytes

decimal degree.name: decimal degree
decimal degree.description: A decimal degree expresses latitude or longitude as decimal fractions.

language code.name: language code
language code.description: A language code conforming to ISO_639-1

float.name: float
float.description: A real number that conforms to the xsd:float specification

double.name: double
double.description: A real number that conforms to the xsd:double specification

decimal.name: decimal
decimal.description: A real number with arbitrary precision that conforms to the xsd:decimal specification

time.name: time
time.description: A time object represents a (local) time of day, independent of any particular day
notes: URI is dateTime because OWL reasoners don't work with straight date or time

date.name: date
date.description: a date (year, month and day) in an idealized calendar
notes: URI is dateTime because OWL reasoners don't work with straight date or time

objectidentifier.name: objectidentifier
objectidentifier.description: A URI or CURIE that represents an object in the model.
comments: Used for inheritence and type checking

nodeidentifier.description: A URI, CURIE or BNODE that represents a node in a model.

data object type.name: data object type
data object type.description: The type of file represented by the data object.

compression type.name: compression type

instrument_name.name: instrument_name
instrument_name.description: The name of the instrument that was used for processing the sample.

gold_path_field.name: gold_path_field
gold_path_field.description: This is a grouping for any of the gold path fields

ecosystem.name: ecosystem
ecosystem.description: An ecosystem is a combination of a physical environment (abiotic factors) and all the organisms (biotic factors) that interact with this environment. Ecosystem is in position 1/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The abiotic factors play a profound role on the type and composition of organisms in a given environment. The GOLD Ecosystem at the top of the five-level classification system is aimed at capturing the broader environment from which an organism or environmental sample is collected. The three broad groups under Ecosystem are Environmental, Host-associated, and Engineered. They represent samples collected from a natural environment or from another organism or from engineered environments like bioreactors respectively.

ecosystem_category.name: ecosystem_category
ecosystem_category.description: Ecosystem categories represent divisions within the ecosystem based on specific characteristics of the environment from where an organism or sample is isolated. Ecosystem category is in position 2/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The Environmental ecosystem (for example) is divided into Air, Aquatic and Terrestrial. Ecosystem categories for Host-associated samples can be individual hosts or phyla and for engineered samples it may be manipulated environments like bioreactors, solid waste etc.

ecosystem_type.name: ecosystem_type
ecosystem_type.description: Ecosystem types represent things having common characteristics within the Ecosystem Category. These common characteristics based grouping is still broad but specific to the characteristics of a given environment. Ecosystem type is in position 3/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The Aquatic ecosystem category (for example) may have ecosystem types like Marine or Thermal springs etc. Ecosystem category Air may have Indoor air or Outdoor air as different Ecosystem Types. In the case of Host-associated samples, ecosystem type can represent Respiratory system, Digestive system, Roots etc.

ecosystem_subtype.name: ecosystem_subtype
ecosystem_subtype.description: Ecosystem subtypes represent further subdivision of Ecosystem types into more distinct subtypes. Ecosystem subtype is in position 4/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: Ecosystem Type Marine (Environmental -> Aquatic -> Marine) is further divided (for example) into Intertidal zone, Coastal, Pelagic, Intertidal zone etc. in the Ecosystem subtype category.

specific_ecosystem.name: specific_ecosystem
specific_ecosystem.description: Specific ecosystems represent specific features of the environment like aphotic zone in an ocean or gastric mucosa within a host digestive system. Specific ecosystem is in position 5/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: Specific ecosystems help to define samples based on very specific characteristics of an environment under the five-level classification system.

principal investigator.name: principal investigator
principal investigator.description: Principal Investigator who led the study and/or generated the dataset.

add_date.name: add_date
add_date.description: The date on which the information was added to the database.

mod_date.name: mod_date
mod_date.description: The last date on which the database information was modified.

ecosystem_path_id.name: ecosystem_path_id
ecosystem_path_id.description: A unique id representing the GOLD classifers associated with a sample.

salinity_category.name: salinity_category
salinity_category.description: Categorcial description of the sample's salinity. Examples: halophile, halotolerant, hypersaline, huryhaline

processing_institution.name: processing_institution
processing_institution.description: The organization that processed the sample.

asm_score.name: asm_score
asm_score.description: A score for comparing metagenomic assembly quality from same sample.

scaffolds.name: scaffolds
scaffolds.description: Total sequence count of all scaffolds.

scaf_logsum.name: scaf_logsum
scaf_logsum.description: The sum of the (length*log(length)) of all scaffolds, times some constant.  Increase the contiguity, the score will increase

scaf_powsum.name: scaf_powsum
scaf_powsum.description: Powersum of all scaffolds is the same as logsum except that it uses the sum of (length*(length^P)) for some power P (default P=0.25).

scaf_bp.name: scaf_bp
scaf_bp.description: Total size in bp of all scaffolds.

scaf_N50.name: scaf_N50
scaf_N50.description: Given a set of scaffolds, each with its own length, the N50 count is defined as the smallest number of scaffolds whose length sum makes up half of genome size.

scaf_N90.name: scaf_N90
scaf_N90.description: Given a set of scaffolds, each with its own length, the N90 count is defined as the smallest number of scaffolds whose length sum makes up 90% of genome size.

scaf_L50.name: scaf_L50
scaf_L50.description: Given a set of scaffolds, the L50 is defined as the sequence length of the shortest scaffold at 50% of the total genome length.

scaf_L90.name: scaf_L90
scaf_L90.description: The L90 statistic is less than or equal to the L50 statistic; it is the length for which the collection of all scaffolds of that length or longer contains at least 90% of the sum of the lengths of all scaffolds.

scaf_n_gt50K.name: scaf_n_gt50K
scaf_n_gt50K.description: Total sequence count of scaffolds greater than 50 KB.

scaf_l_gt50K.name: scaf_l_gt50K
scaf_l_gt50K.description: Total size in bp of all scaffolds greater than 50 KB.

scaf_pct_gt50K.name: scaf_pct_gt50K
scaf_pct_gt50K.description: Total sequence size percentage of scaffolds greater than 50 KB.

contigs.name: contigs
contigs.description: The sum of the (length*log(length)) of all contigs, times some constant.  Increase the contiguity, the score will increase

contig_bp.name: contig_bp
contig_bp.description: Total size in bp of all contigs.

ctg_N50.name: ctg_N50
ctg_N50.description: Given a set of contigs, each with its own length, the N50 count is defined as the smallest number of contigs whose length sum makes up half of genome size.

ctg_L50.name: ctg_L50
ctg_L50.description: Given a set of contigs, the L50 is defined as the sequence length of the shortest contig at 50% of the total genome length.

ctg_N90.name: ctg_N90
ctg_N90.description: Given a set of contigs, each with its own length, the N90 count is defined as the smallest number of contigs whose length sum makes up 90% of genome size.

ctg_L90.name: ctg_L90
ctg_L90.description: The L90 statistic is less than or equal to the L50 statistic; it is the length for which the collection of all contigs of that length or longer contains at least 90% of the sum of the lengths of all contigs.

ctg_powsum.name: ctg_powsum
ctg_powsum.description: Powersum of all contigs is the same as logsum except that it uses the sum of (length*(length^P)) for some power P (default P=0.25).

gap_pct.name: gap_pct
gap_pct.description: The gap size percentage of all scaffolds.

gc_std.name: gc_std
gc_std.description: Standard deviation of GC content of all contigs.

gc_avg.name: gc_avg
gc_avg.description: Average of GC content of all contigs.

num_input_reads.name: num_input_reads
num_input_reads.description: The sequence count number of input reads for assembly.

num_aligned_reads.name: num_aligned_reads
num_aligned_reads.description: The sequence count number of input reads aligned to assembled contigs.

input read count.name: input read count
input read count.description: The sequence count number of input reads for QC analysis.

input base count.name: input base count
input base count.description: The nucleotide base count number of input reads for QC analysis.

output read count.name: output read count
output read count.description: After QC analysis sequence count number.

output base count.name: output base count
output base count.description: After QC analysis nucleotide base count number.

{'the first letter of the accession indicates which partner accepted the initial submission': 'E for ENA, D for DDBJ, or S or N for NCBI.'}

GOLD sequencing project identifiers.description: identifiers for corresponding sequencing project in GOLD

has raw value.description: The value that was specified for an annotation in raw form, i.e. a string. E.g. "2 cm" or "2-4 cm"

has unit.name: has unit
has unit.description: Links a quantity value to a unit

has numeric value.name: has numeric value
has numeric value.description: Links a quantity value to a number

has minimum numeric value.name: has minimum numeric value
has minimum numeric value.description: The minimum value part, expressed as number, of the quantity value when the value covers a range.

has maximum numeric value.name: has maximum numeric value
has maximum numeric value.description: The maximum value part, expressed as number, of the quantity value when the value covers a range.

has boolean value.name: has boolean value
has boolean value.description: Links a quantity value to a boolean

email.name: email
email.description: An email address for an entity such as a person. This should be the primarly email address used.

alternate emails.name: alternate emails
alternate emails.description: One or more other email addresses for an entity.

profile image url.name: profile image url
profile image url.description: A url that points to an image of a person.

has output.name: has output
has output.description: An output biosample to a processing step

part of.name: part of
part of.description: Links a resource to another resource that either logically or physically includes it.

url.name: url
notes: See issue 207 - this clashes with the mixs field

display order.name: display order
display order.description: When rendering information, this attribute to specify the order in which the information should be rendered.

file size bytes.name: file size bytes
file size bytes.description: Size of the file in bytes

abstract.name: abstract
abstract.description: The abstract of manuscript/grant associated with the entity; i.e., a summary of the resource.

keywords.name: keywords
keywords.description: A list of keywords that used to associate the entity. Keywords SHOULD come from controlled vocabularies, including MESH, ENVO.

objective.name: objective
objective.description: The scientific objectives associated with the entity. It SHOULD correspond to scientific norms for objectives field in a structured abstract.

websites.name: websites
websites.description: A list of websites that are associated with the entity.

publications.name: publications
publications.description: A list of publications that are associated with the entity. The publications SHOULD be given using an identifier, such as a DOI or Pubmed ID, if possible.

started at time.name: started at time
comments: The regex for ISO-8601 format was taken from here: https://www.myintervals.com/blog/2009/05/20/iso-8601-date-validation-that-doesnt-suck/ It may not be complete, but it is good enough for now.

ended at time.name: ended at time
comments: The regex for ISO-8601 format was taken from here: https://www.myintervals.com/blog/2009/05/20/iso-8601-date-validation-that-doesnt-suck/ It may not be complete, but it is good enough for now.

id.name: id
id.description: A unique identifier for a thing. Must be either a CURIE shorthand for a URI or a complete URI

name.name: name
name.description: A human readable label for an entity

description.name: description
description.description: a human-readable description of a thing

type.name: type
type.description: An optional string that specifies the type object.  This is used to allow for searches for different kinds of objects.
type.deprecated: Due to confusion about what values are used for this slot, it is best not to use this slot. See https://github.com/microbiomedata/nmdc-schema/issues/248.

title.name: title
title.description: A name given to the entity that differs from the name/label programmatically assigned to it. For example, when extracting study information for GOLD, the GOLD system has assigned a name/label. However, for display purposes, we may also wish the capture the title of the proposal that was used to fund the study.

alternative titles.name: alternative titles
alternative titles.description: A list of alternative titles for the entity. The distinction between title and alternative titles is application-specific.

alternative names.name: alternative names
alternative names.description: A list of alternative names used to refer to the entity. The distinction between name and alternative names is application-specific.

alternative descriptions.name: alternative descriptions
alternative descriptions.description: A list of alternative descriptions for the entity. The distinction between description and alternative descriptions is application-specific.

alternative identifiers.name: alternative identifiers
alternative identifiers.description: A list of alternative identifiers for the entity.

analysis_type.name: analysis_type
analysis_type.description: Select all the data types associated or available for this biosample
analysis_type.title: analysis/data type

sample_link.name: sample_link
sample_link.description: A unique identifier to assign parent-child, subsample, or sibling samples. This is relevant when a sample or other material was used to generate the new sample.
sample_link.title: sample linkage
comments: This field allows multiple entries separated by ; (Examples: Soil collected from the field will link with the soil used in an incubation. The soil a plant was grown in links to the plant sample. An original culture sample was transferred to a new vial and generated a new sample)

collection_date_inc.name: collection_date_inc
collection_date_inc.description: Date the incubation was harvested/collected/ended. Only relevant for incubation samples.
collection_date_inc.title: incubation collection date
notes: MIxS collection_date accepts (truncated) ISO8601. DH taking arb prec date only
comments: Date should be formatted as YYYY(-MM(-DD)). Ie, 2021-04-15, 2021-04 and 2021 are all acceptable.

collection_time.name: collection_time
collection_time.description: The time of sampling, either as an instance (single point) or interval.
collection_time.title: collection time, GMT
notes: MIxS collection_date accepts (truncated) ISO8601. DH taking seconds optional time only
comments: Time should be entered as HH:MM(:SS) in GMT. See here for a converter: https://www.worldtimebuddy.com/pst-to-gmt-converter

collection_time_inc.name: collection_time_inc
collection_time_inc.description: Time the incubation was harvested/collected/ended. Only relevant for incubation samples.
collection_time_inc.title: incubation collection time, GMT
notes: MIxS collection_date accepts (truncated) ISO8601. DH taking seconds optional time only
comments: Time should be entered as HH:MM(:SS) in GMT. See here for a converter: https://www.worldtimebuddy.com/pst-to-gmt-converter

experimental_factor_other.name: experimental_factor_other
experimental_factor_other.description: Other details about your sample that you feel can't be accurately represented in the available columns.
experimental_factor_other.title: experimental factor- other

filter_method.name: filter_method
filter_method.description: Type of filter used or how the sample was filtered
filter_method.title: filter method

isotope_exposure.name: isotope_exposure
isotope_exposure.description: List isotope exposure or addition applied to your sample.
isotope_exposure.title: isotope exposure/addition

micro_biomass_C_meth.name: micro_biomass_C_meth

micro_biomass_C_meth.title: microbial biomass carbon method
comments: required if "microbial_biomass_C" is provided

micro_biomass_N_meth.name: micro_biomass_N_meth
micro_biomass_N_meth.description: Reference or method used in determining microbial biomass nitrogen
micro_biomass_N_meth.title: microbial biomass nitrogen method
comments: required if "microbial_biomass_N" is provided

microbial_biomass_C.name: microbial_biomass_C
microbial_biomass_C.description: The part of the organic matter in the soil that constitutes living microorganisms smaller than 5-10 micrometer. If you keep this, you would need to have correction factors used for conversion to the final units
microbial_biomass_C.title: microbial biomass carbon

microbial_biomass_N.name: microbial_biomass_N
microbial_biomass_N.description: The part of the organic matter in the soil that constitutes living microorganisms smaller than 5-10 micrometer. If you keep this, you would need to have correction factors used for conversion to the final units
microbial_biomass_N.title: microbial biomass nitrogen

non_microb_biomass.name: non_microb_biomass
non_microb_biomass.description: Amount of biomass; should include the name for the part of biomass measured, e.g.insect, plant, total. Can include multiple measurements separated by ;
non_microb_biomass.title: non-microbial biomass

non_microb_biomass_method.name: non_microb_biomass_method
non_microb_biomass_method.description: Reference or method used in determining biomass
non_microb_biomass_method.title: non-microbial biomass method
comments: required if "non-microbial biomass" is provided

org_nitro_method.name: org_nitro_method
org_nitro_method.description: Method used for obtaining organic nitrogen
org_nitro_method.title: organic nitrogen method
comments: required if "org_nitro" is provided

other_treatment.name: other_treatment
other_treatment.description: Other treatments applied to your samples that are not applicable to the provided fields
other_treatment.title: other treatments

start_date_inc.name: start_date_inc
start_date_inc.description: Date the incubation was started. Only relevant for incubation samples.
start_date_inc.title: incubation start date
notes: MIxS collection_date accepts (truncated) ISO8601. DH taking arb prec date only
comments: Date should be formatted as YYYY(-MM(-DD)). Ie, 2021-04-15, 2021-04 and 2021 are all acceptable.

start_time_inc.name: start_time_inc
start_time_inc.description: Time the incubation was started. Only relevant for incubation samples.
start_time_inc.title: incubation start time, GMT
notes: MIxS collection_date accepts (truncated) ISO8601. DH taking seconds optional time only
comments: Time should be entered as HH:MM(:SS) in GMT. See here for a converter: https://www.worldtimebuddy.com/pst-to-gmt-converter

dnase_rna.name: dnase_rna
dnase_rna.title: DNase treated
comments: Note DNAse treatment is required for all RNA samples.

proposal_rna.name: proposal_rna
proposal_rna.title: RNA proposal ID
comments: Do not edit these values. A template will be provided by NMDC in which these values have been pre-filled.

rna_absorb1.name: rna_absorb1
rna_absorb1.title: RNA absorbance 260/280
comments: Recommended value is between 1 and 3.

rna_absorb2.name: rna_absorb2
rna_absorb2.title: RNA absorbance 260/230
comments: Recommended value is between 1 and 3.

rna_collect_site.name: rna_collect_site
rna_collect_site.description: Provide information on the site your RNA sample was collected from
rna_collect_site.title: RNA collection site

rna_concentration.name: rna_concentration
rna_concentration.title: RNA concentration in ng/ul
comments: Units must be in ng/uL. Enter the numerical part only. Must be calculated using a fluorometric method. Acceptable values are 0-2000.

rna_cont_well.name: rna_cont_well
rna_cont_well.title: RNA well number
comments: Required when 'plate' is selected for container type. Corner wells must be blank. For partial plates, fill by columns. Leave blank if the sample will be shipped in a tube.

rna_container_ID.name: rna_container_ID
rna_container_ID.title: RNA container label
comments: Must be unique across all tubes and plates, and <20 characters. All samples in a plate should have the same plate label.

rna_isolate_meth.name: rna_isolate_meth
rna_isolate_meth.description: Describe the method/protocol/kit used to extract DNA/RNA.
rna_isolate_meth.title: RNA isolation method

rna_organisms.name: rna_organisms
rna_organisms.description: List any organisms known or suspected to grow in co-culture, as well as estimated % of the organism in that culture.
rna_organisms.title: RNA expected organisms

examples.value: expected to contain microbes (59%) fungi (30%), viruses (10%), tadpoles (1%)

elev.name: elev
elev.description: Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit.
elev.title: elevation

elevator.name: elevator
elevator.description: The number of elevators within the built structure
elevator.title: elevator count

emulsions.name: emulsions
emulsions.description: Amount or concentration of substances such as paints, adhesives, mayonnaise, hair colorants, emulsified oils, etc.; can include multiple emulsion types
emulsions.title: emulsions

env_broad_scale.name: env_broad_scale

expected_value.value: The major environment type(s) where the sample was collected. Recommend subclasses of biome [ENVO:00000428]. Multiple terms can be separated by one or more pipes.

env_broad_scale.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class:  http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS
env_broad_scale.title: broad-scale environmental context

examples.value: oceanic epipelagic zone biome [ENVO:01000033] for annotating a water sample from the photic zone in middle of the Atlantic Ocean

env_local_scale.name: env_local_scale

expected_value.value: Environmental entities having causal influences upon the entity at time of sampling.

env_local_scale.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for env_broad_scale. Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.
env_local_scale.title: local environmental context

examples.value: litter layer [ENVO:01000338]; Annotating a pooled sample taken from various vegetation layers in a forest consider: canopy [ENVO:00000047]|herb and fern layer [ENVO:01000337]|litter layer [ENVO:01000338]|understory [01000335]|shrub layer [ENVO:01000336].

env_medium.name: env_medium

expected_value.value: The material displaced by the entity at time of sampling. Recommend subclasses of environmental material [ENVO:00010483].

env_medium.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).
env_medium.title: environmental medium

examples.value: soil [ENVO:00001998]; Annotating a fish swimming in the upper 100 m of the Atlantic Ocean, consider: ocean water [ENVO:00002151]. Example: Annotating a duck on a pond consider: pond water [ENVO:00002228]|air [ENVO_00002005]

This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

flooding.name: flooding

fluor.description: Raw or converted fluorescence of water

fungicide_regm.description: Information about treatment involving use of fungicides; should include the name of fungicide, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple fungicide regimens
fungicide_regm.title: fungicide regimen

furniture.name: furniture
furniture.description: The types of furniture present in the sampled room
furniture.title: furniture

expected_value.value: gaseous compound name;gaseous compound amount;treatment interval and duration

gaseous_substances.description: Amount or concentration of substances such as hydrogen sulfide, carbon dioxide, methane, etc.; can include multiple substances

geo_loc_name.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)

gravidity.name: gravidity

expected_value.value: gravity factor value;treatment interval and duration

growth_hormone_regm.description: Information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of growth hormone, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple growth hormone regimens
growth_hormone_regm.title: growth hormone regimen

hall_count.name: hall_count

hcr.name: hcr
hcr.description: Main Hydrocarbon Resource type. The term "Hydrocarbon Resource" HCR defined as a natural environmental feature containing large amounts of hydrocarbons at high concentrations potentially suitable for commercial exploitation. This term should not be confused with the Hydrocarbon Occurrence term which also includes hydrocarbon-rich environments with currently limited commercial interest such as seeps, outcrops, gas hydrates etc. If "other" is specified, please propose entry in "additional info" field

hcr_geol_age.name: hcr_geol_age

hcr_pressure.name: hcr_pressure

hcr_temp.name: hcr_temp

hcr_temp.title: hydrocarbon resource original temperature

height_carper_fiber.name: height_carper_fiber
height_carper_fiber.description: The average carpet fiber height in the indoor environment
height_carper_fiber.title: height carpet fiber mat

herbicide_regm.name: herbicide_regm

expected_value.value: herbicide name;herbicide amount;treatment interval and duration

preferred_unit.value: gram, mole per liter, milligram per liter

herbicide_regm.description: Information about treatment involving use of herbicides; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of herbicide, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens

horizon_meth.description: Reference or method used in determining the horizon

host_sex.name: host_sex

Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123.

This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater.

samp_loc_corr_rate.name: samp_loc_corr_rate

Therefore, long term corrosion rates are generally more informative than short term rates and for that reason they are preferred during reporting. In the case of suspected MIC, corrosion rate measurements at the time of sampling might provide insights into the involvement of certain microbial community members in MIC as well as potential microbial interplays

In deviated wells, the MD is the length of trajectory of the borehole measured from the same reference or datum. Common datums used are ground level (GL), drilling rig floor (DF), rotary table (RT), kelly bushing (KB) and mean sea level (MSL). INSDC requires every sample name from a single Submitter to be unique. Use of a globally unique identifier for the field source_mat_id is recommended in addition to sample_name.

source_mat_id.name: source_mat_id

expected_value.value: for cultures of microorganisms: identifiers for two culture collections; for other material a unique arbitrary identifer

source_mat_id.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).
source_mat_id.title: source material identifiers

elev.name: elev

Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit.
elev.title: elevation

env_package.name: env_package
env_package.description: MIxS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. All environmental packages listed here are further defined in separate subtables. By giving the name of the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from the subtables and can be reported

env_broad_scale.name: env_broad_scale
env_broad_scale.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class:  http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS
env_broad_scale.title: broad-scale environmental context

env_local_scale.name: env_local_scale
env_local_scale.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for env_broad_scale. Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.
env_local_scale.title: local environmental context

env_medium.name: env_medium
env_medium.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).
env_medium.title: environmental medium

ecosystem.name: ecosystem
ecosystem.description: An ecosystem is a combination of a physical environment (abiotic factors) and all the organisms (biotic factors) that interact with this environment. Ecosystem is in position 1/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The abiotic factors play a profound role on the type and composition of organisms in a given environment. The GOLD Ecosystem at the top of the five-level classification system is aimed at capturing the broader environment from which an organism or environmental sample is collected. The three broad groups under Ecosystem are Environmental, Host-associated, and Engineered. They represent samples collected from a natural environment or from another organism or from engineered environments like bioreactors respectively.

ecosystem_category.name: ecosystem_category
ecosystem_category.description: Ecosystem categories represent divisions within the ecosystem based on specific characteristics of the environment from where an organism or sample is isolated. Ecosystem category is in position 2/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The Environmental ecosystem (for example) is divided into Air, Aquatic and Terrestrial. Ecosystem categories for Host-associated samples can be individual hosts or phyla and for engineered samples it may be manipulated environments like bioreactors, solid waste etc.

ecosystem_type.name: ecosystem_type
ecosystem_type.description: Ecosystem types represent things having common characteristics within the Ecosystem Category. These common characteristics based grouping is still broad but specific to the characteristics of a given environment. Ecosystem type is in position 3/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The Aquatic ecosystem category (for example) may have ecosystem types like Marine or Thermal springs etc. Ecosystem category Air may have Indoor air or Outdoor air as different Ecosystem Types. In the case of Host-associated samples, ecosystem type can represent Respiratory system, Digestive system, Roots etc.

ecosystem_subtype.name: ecosystem_subtype
ecosystem_subtype.description: Ecosystem subtypes represent further subdivision of Ecosystem types into more distinct subtypes. Ecosystem subtype is in position 4/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: Ecosystem Type Marine (Environmental -> Aquatic -> Marine) is further divided (for example) into Intertidal zone, Coastal, Pelagic, Intertidal zone etc. in the Ecosystem subtype category.

specific_ecosystem.name: specific_ecosystem
specific_ecosystem.description: Specific ecosystems represent specific features of the environment like aphotic zone in an ocean or gastric mucosa within a host digestive system. Specific ecosystem is in position 5/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: Specific ecosystems help to define samples based on very specific characteristics of an environment under the five-level classification system.

For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI

source_mat_id.name: source_mat_id

expected_value.value: for cultures of microorganisms: identifiers for two culture collections; for other material a unique arbitrary identifer

source_mat_id.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).
source_mat_id.title: source material identifiers

ecosystem.name: ecosystem
ecosystem.description: An ecosystem is a combination of a physical environment (abiotic factors) and all the organisms (biotic factors) that interact with this environment. Ecosystem is in position 1/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The abiotic factors play a profound role on the type and composition of organisms in a given environment. The GOLD Ecosystem at the top of the five-level classification system is aimed at capturing the broader environment from which an organism or environmental sample is collected. The three broad groups under Ecosystem are Environmental, Host-associated, and Engineered. They represent samples collected from a natural environment or from another organism or from engineered environments like bioreactors respectively.

ecosystem_category.name: ecosystem_category
ecosystem_category.description: Ecosystem categories represent divisions within the ecosystem based on specific characteristics of the environment from where an organism or sample is isolated. Ecosystem category is in position 2/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The Environmental ecosystem (for example) is divided into Air, Aquatic and Terrestrial. Ecosystem categories for Host-associated samples can be individual hosts or phyla and for engineered samples it may be manipulated environments like bioreactors, solid waste etc.

ecosystem_type.name: ecosystem_type
ecosystem_type.description: Ecosystem types represent things having common characteristics within the Ecosystem Category. These common characteristics based grouping is still broad but specific to the characteristics of a given environment. Ecosystem type is in position 3/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: The Aquatic ecosystem category (for example) may have ecosystem types like Marine or Thermal springs etc. Ecosystem category Air may have Indoor air or Outdoor air as different Ecosystem Types. In the case of Host-associated samples, ecosystem type can represent Respiratory system, Digestive system, Roots etc.

ecosystem_subtype.name: ecosystem_subtype
ecosystem_subtype.description: Ecosystem subtypes represent further subdivision of Ecosystem types into more distinct subtypes. Ecosystem subtype is in position 4/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: Ecosystem Type Marine (Environmental -> Aquatic -> Marine) is further divided (for example) into Intertidal zone, Coastal, Pelagic, Intertidal zone etc. in the Ecosystem subtype category.

specific_ecosystem.name: specific_ecosystem
specific_ecosystem.description: Specific ecosystems represent specific features of the environment like aphotic zone in an ocean or gastric mucosa within a host digestive system. Specific ecosystem is in position 5/5 in a GOLD path.
comments: Specific ecosystems help to define samples based on very specific characteristics of an environment under the five-level classification system.

samp_vol_we_dna_ext.description: Volume (ml) or mass (g) of total collected sample processed for DNA extraction. Note: total sample collected should be entered under the term Sample Size (MIXS:0000001).
samp_vol_we_dna_ext.title: sample volume or weight for DNA extraction
aliases: sample volume or weight for DNA extraction

nucl_acid_ext.name: nucl_acid_ext
nucl_acid_ext.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample
nucl_acid_ext.title: nucleic acid extraction

nucl_acid_amp.name: nucl_acid_amp
nucl_acid_amp.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the enzymatic amplification (PCR, TMA, NASBA) of specific nucleic acids
nucl_acid_amp.title: nucleic acid amplification

target_gene.name: target_gene
target_gene.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies
target_gene.title: target gene

target_subfragment.name: target_subfragment
target_subfragment.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA
target_subfragment.title: target subfragment

pcr_primers.name: pcr_primers

expected_value.value: FWD: forward primer sequence;REV:reverse primer sequence

pcr_primers.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters
pcr_primers.title: pcr primers

pcr_cond.name: pcr_cond
pcr_cond.description: Description of reaction conditions and components of PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'
pcr_cond.title: pcr conditions

seq_meth.name: seq_meth
seq_meth.description: Sequencing machine used. Where possible the term should be taken from the OBI list of DNA sequencers (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0400103).
seq_meth.title: sequencing method

seq_quality_check.name: seq_quality_check
seq_quality_check.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA,ENA or DRA
seq_quality_check.title: sequence quality check

chimera_check.name: chimera_check

expected_value.value: name and version of software, parameters used

chimera_check.description: Tool(s) used for chimera checking, including version number and parameters, to discover and remove chimeric sequences. A chimeric sequence is comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences.
chimera_check.title: chimera check software

scaffolds.name: scaffolds
scaffolds.description: Total sequence count of all scaffolds.

scaf_logsum.name: scaf_logsum
scaf_logsum.description: The sum of the (length*log(length)) of all scaffolds, times some constant.  Increase the contiguity, the score will increase

scaf_powsum.name: scaf_powsum
scaf_powsum.description: Powersum of all scaffolds is the same as logsum except that it uses the sum of (length*(length^P)) for some power P (default P=0.25).

scaf_bp.name: scaf_bp
scaf_bp.description: Total size in bp of all scaffolds.

scaf_N50.name: scaf_N50
scaf_N50.description: Given a set of scaffolds, each with its own length, the N50 count is defined as the smallest number of scaffolds whose length sum makes up half of genome size.

scaf_N90.name: scaf_N90
scaf_N90.description: Given a set of scaffolds, each with its own length, the N90 count is defined as the smallest number of scaffolds whose length sum makes up 90% of genome size.

scaf_L50.name: scaf_L50
scaf_L50.description: Given a set of scaffolds, the L50 is defined as the sequence length of the shortest scaffold at 50% of the total genome length.

scaf_L90.name: scaf_L90
scaf_L90.description: The L90 statistic is less than or equal to the L50 statistic; it is the length for which the collection of all scaffolds of that length or longer contains at least 90% of the sum of the lengths of all scaffolds.

scaf_n_gt50K.name: scaf_n_gt50K
scaf_n_gt50K.description: Total sequence count of scaffolds greater than 50 KB.

scaf_l_gt50K.name: scaf_l_gt50K
scaf_l_gt50K.description: Total size in bp of all scaffolds greater than 50 KB.

scaf_pct_gt50K.name: scaf_pct_gt50K
scaf_pct_gt50K.description: Total sequence size percentage of scaffolds greater than 50 KB.

contigs.name: contigs
contigs.description: The sum of the (length*log(length)) of all contigs, times some constant.  Increase the contiguity, the score will increase

contig_bp.name: contig_bp
contig_bp.description: Total size in bp of all contigs.

ctg_N50.name: ctg_N50
ctg_N50.description: Given a set of contigs, each with its own length, the N50 count is defined as the smallest number of contigs whose length sum makes up half of genome size.

ctg_L50.name: ctg_L50
ctg_L50.description: Given a set of contigs, the L50 is defined as the sequence length of the shortest contig at 50% of the total genome length.

ctg_N90.name: ctg_N90
ctg_N90.description: Given a set of contigs, each with its own length, the N90 count is defined as the smallest number of contigs whose length sum makes up 90% of genome size.

ctg_L90.name: ctg_L90
ctg_L90.description: The L90 statistic is less than or equal to the L50 statistic; it is the length for which the collection of all contigs of that length or longer contains at least 90% of the sum of the lengths of all contigs.

ctg_powsum.name: ctg_powsum
ctg_powsum.description: Powersum of all contigs is the same as logsum except that it uses the sum of (length*(length^P)) for some power P (default P=0.25).

gap_pct.name: gap_pct
gap_pct.description: The gap size percentage of all scaffolds.

gc_std.name: gc_std
gc_std.description: Standard deviation of GC content of all contigs.

gc_avg.name: gc_avg
gc_avg.description: Average of GC content of all contigs.

type.deprecated: Due to confusion about what values are used for this slot, it is best not to use this slot. See https://github.com/microbiomedata/nmdc-schema/issues/248.

instrument.name: instrument
instrument.description: A material entity that is designed to perform a function in a scientific investigation, but is not a reagent[OBI].

id.name: id
id.description: A unique identifier for a thing. Must be either a CURIE shorthand for a URI or a complete URI

name.name: name
name.description: A human readable label for an entity

description.name: description
description.description: a human-readable description of a thing

alternative identifiers.name: alternative identifiers
alternative identifiers.description: A list of alternative identifiers for the entity.

metabolite quantification.name: metabolite quantification
metabolite quantification.description: This is used to link a metabolomics analysis workflow to a specific metabolite

alternative identifiers.name: alternative identifiers
alternative identifiers.description: A list of alternative identifiers for the entity.

peptide quantification.name: peptide quantification
peptide quantification.description: This is used to link a metaproteomics analysis workflow to a specific peptide sequence and related information

best protein.name: best protein
best protein.description: the specific protein identifier most correctly associated with the peptide sequence

all proteins.name: all proteins
all proteins.description: the list of protein identifiers that are associated with the peptide sequence

min_q_value.name: min_q_value
min_q_value.description: smallest Q-Value associated with the peptide sequence as provided by MSGFPlus tool

peptide_spectral_count.name: peptide_spectral_count
peptide_spectral_count.description: sum of filter passing MS2 spectra associated with the peptide sequence within a given LC-MS/MS data file

peptide_sum_masic_abundance.name: peptide_sum_masic_abundance
peptide_sum_masic_abundance.description: combined MS1 extracted ion chromatograms derived from MS2 spectra associated with the peptide sequence from a given LC-MS/MS data file using the MASIC tool

protein quantification.name: protein quantification
protein quantification.description: This is used to link a metaproteomics analysis workflow to a specific protein

best protein.name: best protein
best protein.description: the specific protein identifier most correctly grouped to its associated peptide sequences

all proteins.name: all proteins
all proteins.description: the grouped list of protein identifiers associated with the peptide sequences that were grouped to a best protein

peptide_sequence_count.name: peptide_sequence_count
peptide_sequence_count.description: count of peptide sequences grouped to the best_protein

protein_spectral_count.name: protein_spectral_count
protein_spectral_count.description: sum of filter passing MS2 spectra associated with the best protein within a given LC-MS/MS data file

protein_sum_masic_abundance.name: protein_sum_masic_abundance
protein_sum_masic_abundance.description: combined MS1 extracted ion chromatograms derived from MS2 spectra associated with the best protein from a given LC-MS/MS data file using the MASIC tool

chemical entity.name: chemical entity
chemical entity.description: An atom or molecule that can be represented with a chemical formula. Include lipids, glycans, natural products, drugs. There may be different terms for distinct acid-base forms, protonation states

smiles.name: smiles
smiles.description: A string encoding of a molecular graph, no chiral or isotopic information. There are usually a large number of valid SMILES which represent a given structure. For example, CCO, OCC and C(O)C all specify the structure of ethanol.

chemical formula.name: chemical formula
chemical formula.description: A generic grouping for miolecular formulae and empirican formulae

description.description: a human-readable description of a thing

gene product.description: A molecule encoded by a gene that has an evolved function

id.name: id
id.description: A unique identifier for a thing. Must be either a CURIE shorthand for a URI or a complete URI

name.name: name
name.description: A human readable label for an entity

started at time.name: started at time
comments: The regex for ISO-8601 format was taken from here: https://www.myintervals.com/blog/2009/05/20/iso-8601-date-validation-that-doesnt-suck/ It may not be complete, but it is good enough for now.

ended at time.name: ended at time
comments: The regex for ISO-8601 format was taken from here: https://www.myintervals.com/blog/2009/05/20/iso-8601-date-validation-that-doesnt-suck/ It may not be complete, but it is good enough for now.

genome feature.name: genome feature
genome feature.description: A feature localized to an interval along a genome
comments: corresponds to an entry in GFF3

seqid.name: seqid
seqid.description: The ID of the landmark used to establish the coordinate system for the current feature.

type.name: type
type.description: A type from the sequence ontology

start.name: start
start.description: The start of the feature in positive 1-based integer coordinates

end.name: end
end.description: The end of the feature in positive 1-based integer coordinates
comments: - "constraint: end > start" - "For features that cross the origin of a circular feature,  end = the position of the end + the length of the landmark feature."

strand.name: strand
strand.description: The strand on which a feature is located. Has a value of '+' (sense strand or forward strand) or '-' (anti-sense strand or reverse strand).

phase.name: phase
phase.description: The phase for a coding sequence entity. For example, phase of a CDS as represented in a GFF3 with a value of 0, 1 or 2.

encodes.name: encodes
encodes.description: The gene product encoded by this feature. Typically this is used for a CDS feature or gene feature which will encode a protein. It can also be used by a nc transcript ot gene feature that encoded a ncRNA

functional annotation term.name: functional annotation term
functional annotation term.description: Abstract grouping class for any term/descriptor that can be applied to a functional unit of a genome (protein, ncRNA, complex).
todos: decide if this should be used for product naming

functional annotation.name: functional annotation
functional annotation.description: An assignment of a function term (e.g. reaction or pathway) that is executed by a gene product, or which the gene product plays an active role in. Functional annotations can be assigned manually by curators, or automatically in workflows. In the context of NMDC, all function annotation is performed automatically, typically using HMM or Blast type methods
